title: 105_s2326
content: The Act is titled the "Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998" and includes definitions for key terms. The Act defines key terms such as "child" as an individual under 16, "children" as more than one child, and "commercial website operator" as a person operating a website for commercial purposes involving commerce across states or nations. The Act defines key terms related to personal information disclosure, including the definition of "Commission" as the Federal Trade Commission and "Federal agency" as a government agency. The Act defines key terms related to personal information disclosure, including "Federal agency" as an agency defined in title 5, United States Code, and "Internet" as an international computer network. The term "parent" is also defined as a legal guardian, and "personal information" includes identifiable information about an individual such as name, address, email, phone number, and Social Security number. The Act defines key terms related to personal information disclosure, including "Federal agency" and "Internet." Verifiable parental consent is required before collecting personal information from a child on a website directed to children. This includes any information that enables locating and contacting a specific individual. The Act defines "person" as any entity, and specifies that a commercial website directed to children must not collect information without parental consent. SEC. 3. REGULATION OF UNFAIR AND DECEPTIVE ACTS AND PRACTICES IN CONNECTION WITH THE COLLECTION AND USE OF PERSONAL INFORMATION FROM AND ABOUT CHILDREN ON THE INTERNET. The Commission must prescribe regulations within a year of this Act's enactment, requiring commercial website operators to follow fair information practices when collecting personal information from children. These regulations should include clear notice and obtain parental consent for websites directed at children. The regulations require obtaining parental consent for collecting personal information from children under 13 and providing parents with notice and control over information collected from children aged 12 to 17. Parents must have access to their child's information and the ability to refuse further use. The regulations mandate parental consent for collecting personal information from children under 13 and giving parents control over data collected from children aged 12 to 17. Commercial website operators must establish procedures to safeguard the confidentiality and accuracy of children's personal information. Enforcement treats violations as unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Enforcement of regulations for collecting personal information from children under 13 treats violations as unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act. SEC. 4. SAFE HARBORS. The Commission will incentivize self-regulation by website operators to implement protections. Safe Harbors will ensure compliance with regulations if guidelines approved by the Commission are followed. SEC. 5. ACTIONS BY STATES. The attorney general of a State can bring a civil action in federal court to address violations of Commission regulations that harm residents, seeking injunctions, compliance, damages, or other appropriate relief. Before filing an action under paragraph (1), the attorney general of the State must provide written notice and a copy of the complaint to the Commission. An exemption applies if the attorney general determines it is not feasible to provide notice before filing the action. The attorney general must provide notice and a copy of the complaint to the Commission before filing an action. The Commission has the right to intervene in the action and be heard on any matter that arises, as well as file a petition for appeal. (c) Construction.--For purposes of bringing any civil action under subsection (a), nothing in this Act shall be construed to prevent an attorney general of a State from conducting investigations, administering oaths or affirmations, or compelling the attendance of witnesses or the production of evidence. In any case where the Commission initiates an action for violation of regulations, no State can file a separate action against the same defendant during the pending Commission action. Venue for actions under subsection (a) can be in the district court where the defendant is found, is an inhabitant, transacts business, or meets venue requirements under section 1391 of title 28, US Code. Process serving can occur in any district where the defendant is an inhabitant or can be found. Other state officials are not restricted by this section. The section allows State officials to proceed in State courts for alleged violations of State laws. Other State officers authorized by the State can also bring such actions on behalf of residents. SEC. 6. ADMINISTRATION AND APPLICABILITY OF ACT. This Act will be enforced by the Commission under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Compliance with the requirements will be enforced under section 8 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act for national banks, Federal branches, Federal agencies of foreign banks, member banks of the Federal Reserve System, branches and agencies of foreign banks, commercial lending companies owned or controlled by foreign banks. The Federal Reserve Act, Federal Deposit Insurance Act, and Federal Credit Union Act are enforced by different regulatory bodies such as the Board, Board of Directors of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and National Credit Union Administration Board respectively. The Farm Credit Act of 1971, Packers and Stockyards Act, and part A of subtitle VII of title 49 are enforced by specific agencies like the Farm Credit Administration and Secretary of Agriculture. These agencies have the authority to exercise powers under the mentioned Acts. The agencies mentioned in the previous paragraph have the authority to enforce compliance with requirements under the Act. The Commission will enforce rules under section 3 with the same powers as the Federal Trade Commission Act. Entities violating these rules will face penalties and have certain privileges. The Act grants agencies the authority to enforce compliance with its requirements, subject to penalties and entitled to privileges and immunities provided in the Federal Trade Commission Act. This includes jurisdiction, power, and duties similar to the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Act does not limit the Commission's authority under other laws. SEC. 7. REVIEW. The Commission shall review the implementation of the Act after 5 years and submit a report to Congress on its effects on information disclosure practices related to children.
